title: U.S. and European bond yields fall sharply after ECB restarts bond-buying operation
text:
U.S. Treasury yields and European government bond yields fell sharply on Thursday after the European Central Bank lowered its key deposit rate and exceeded investors expectations with the resumption of its bond-buying program.

What are Treasurys doing?

The 10-year Treasury note yield TMUBMUSD10Y, -3.66% was down a single basis point to 1.723%, while the 2-year note rate TMUBMUSD02Y, -3.12% was virtually unchanged to 1.672%. The 30-year bond yield TMUBMUSD30Y, -3.20% fell 0.7 basis point to 2.201%.

The German 10-year government bond yield TMBMKDE-10Y, -14.47% plunged 7.3 basis points to negative 0.637%, while the 10-year Italian bond yield TMBMKIT-10Y, -19.38% fell 16 basis points to 0.823%, briefly scraping a record low of 0.79%.

What’s driving Treasurys?

The ECB spurred buying in global bond markets after the central bank cut its deposit rate by 10 basis points to a negative 0.5% as expected. More importantly, it announced it would buy $20 billion of bonds every month, despite doubts among analysts who said the possible universe of European bonds available for purchase was shrinking.

A month ago, ECB policymaker Olli Rehn had suggested it would make sense for the central bank to surprise investors with an ambitious stimulus package in order to achieve its maximum impact. However, dissent with the ranks of the ECB in recent days had cast doubt on the likelihood that the central bank would resume its bond-buying operations in September.

ECB President Mario Draghi will speak next at a press conference at 8:30 a.m Eastern.

See: ECB cuts deposit rate, restarts bond-buying program

Investors saw some positive news on the international trade front. President Donald Trump delayed a tariff increase on around $250 billion in Chinese imports that had been originally slated to start on Oct. 1. Trump postponed the increase to Oct. 15, to avoid conflicting with the 70th anniversary of the Chinese Communist Party’s rule.

The Wall Street Journal reported that Beijing was looking to split trade negotiations into two tracks, separating the more thornier national security issues from less contentious trade concerns, in the hopes of advancing stalled trade talks with the U.S.

Market participants will also consider an update on U.S. inflationary pressures. The U.S. consumer price data for August will be published at 8:30 a.m. Eastern Time, with economists surveyed by MarketWatch anticipating an increase of 0.1% for the month.

What did market participants’ say?

“Combining a 10 bp rate cut, providing more accommodative forward guidance, and restarting quantitative easing, the ECB has out-doved expectations,” said Jon Hill, an interest-rate analyst at BMO Capital Markets.

“If one of the core fundamental justifications for the backup in rates we’ve seen over recent days was concern that Draghi couldn’t garner support for an easier stance of monetary policy, this clears the way for a push back to range lows ahead of next week’s FOMC,” said Hill.
